skills.name: Use inequality notation to order negative integers with the same number of digits
Find the absolute value of a number
Compare absolute values using inequality notation
Relate a negative number as an absolute distance from 0 on a number line

explanations.A: Not quite - distance can't be a negative value, even when it is a negative number.
explanations.B: It seems like you might have added the positive and negative version together, but remember we are counting how far away it is from 0!
explanations.C: -10 is 10 numbers back from 0, so the distance would be 10.
explanations.D: The distance is how many numbers a value is away from something. Try thinking about how many jumps on a number line you'd have to make to get from 0 to -10!

explanations.A: It seems like you might have added the positive and negative version together, but remember we are counting how far away it is from 0!
explanations.B: -20 is 20 numbers back from 0, so the distance would be 20.
explanations.C: Not quite - distance can't be a negative value, even when it is a negative number.
explanations.D: The distance is how many numbers a value is away from something. Try thinking about how many jumps on a number line you'd have to make to get from 0 to -20!

explanations.A: 8 is 8 numbers away from 0, so the distance would be 8.
explanations.B: It seems like you might have just given the negative version of the number, but remember we are counting how far away it is from 0!
explanations.C: It seems like you might have added the positive and negative version together, but remember we are counting how far away it is from 0!
explanations.D: ∣8∣ means the absolute value of 8, which is asking you how far away from 0 the number 8 is! Think about it as counting jumps of 1.

explanations.A: It seems like you might have just given the negative version of the number, but remember we are counting how far away it is from 0!
explanations.B: It seems like you might have added the positive and negative version together, but remember we are counting how far away it is from 0!
explanations.C: 4 is 4 numbers away from 0, which means the absolute value of 4 is 4.
explanations.D: ∣4∣ means the absolute value of 4, which is asking you how far away from 0 the number 4 is! Think about it as counting jumps of 1.

explanations.A: > means greater than, and -60 is closer to 0 than -75 which means it has a greater value.
explanations.B: For negative numbers, the closer it is to 0, the greater it is. These two numbers definitely aren't equal to each other as they don't have the same digits!
explanations.C: It seems like you might think that a number further away from 0 means it is bigger, however we are thinking about which number is greater and for negative numbers they are greater the closer they get to 0.
explanations.D: A number will always be greater than, equal to or less than another number. If we placed these on a number line, which one would be the greatest?

explanations.A: It seems like you might think that a number further away from 0 means it is bigger, however we are thinking about which number is greater and for negative numbers they are greater the closer they get to 0.
explanations.B: For negative numbers, the closer it is to 0, the greater it is. These two numbers definitely aren't equal to each other as they don't have the same digits!
explanations.C: > means greater than, and -40 is closer to 0 than -60 which means it has a greater value.
explanations.D: A number will always be greater than, equal to or less than another number. If we placed these on a number line, which one would be the greatest?

explanations.A: Remember that |x| notation means absolute value, so here we are comparing which one is further from 0.
explanations.B: I think you may have misread what numbers we are comparing here!
explanations.C: The absolute value of -14 is less than the absolute value of -41 as it is much closer to 0.
explanations.D: We can still use inequalities to compare absolute values of numbers!

explanations.A: The absolute value of -62 is greater than the absolute value of -26 as it is much further away from 0.
explanations.B: I think you may have misread what numbers we are comparing here!
explanations.C: Remember that |x| notation means absolute value, so here we are comparing which one is further from 0.
explanations.D: We can still use inequalities to compare absolute values of numbers!

explanations.A: Remember that |x| notation means absolute value, so here we are comparing how far away the numbers are from 0 rather than the numbers themselves.
explanations.B: Both 42 and -42 have an absolute value of 42 away from 0. This means their absolute values are both equal!
explanations.C: Remember that |x| notation means absolute value, so here we are comparing how far away the numbers are from 0.
explanations.D: We can still use inequalities to compare absolute values of numbers!

explanations.A: Remember that |x| notation means absolute value, so here we are comparing how far away the numbers are from 0 rather than the numbers themselves.
explanations.B: Remember that |x| notation means absolute value, so here we are comparing how far away the numbers are from 0.

explanations.D: We can still use inequalities to compare absolute values of numbers!
